title: Is the movie for The Great Gatsby accurate in relation to the book? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes and no. For example, there is no mention of Nick’s being mentally disturbed and hospitalized in the novel, though this addition to the plot in Luhrmann’s film seems to me justified because it hints at just how profoundly the tragedy of Gatsby’s death—with all its symbolic import for America—has affected Nick. Some of the music in the film is anachronistic. However, as someone who has led many college level discussions on the novel, I say that the film is as close to a perfect cinematic adaptation of a great book as I have ever seen. I was getting goose bumps in the theater. I have heard a lot of nit picking complaints about the overuse of CGI in the film, but I can’t take those very seriously. It’s a wonderful film. I wish I had a way to watch it at home in 3D because it does resonate so well with the book.

As far as movie adaptions of famous novels go, its more faithful than most. It’s also much more fun. As Mr. Milliman has already pointed out, the framing device of Nick writing his account as part of some sort of recovery, isn’t in the book. See the Wikipedia article on the film for Breanne L. Healman’s list of four other (fairly minor) departures from the novel. However, she fails to mention that the director also cut Gatsby’s father appearance at his funeral.
Read it and find out. There are 3 movie versions of which I am aware. But the Redford Gatsby is the best IMNSHO
